comments.commentBody:
Dedicated to the True Blue Knick FANS

http://www.youtube.com...

What was the point of the trade to get Brewer?  If Randolph could have gotten a No 1 from MN, why did Knicks trade Randolph for Brewer?  Can anyone explain that trade I have failed to read an explanation anywhere.  I assume MN was under the cap and could absorb $12 million.  I dont think Brewer earns anywhere near that.

Sorry, but this analysis is inherently flawed. For starters, it's not like Brewer was taking a massive amount of outside shots. Based on your chart, he essentially shoots as many outside shots as the league average. Also, it's wrong to suggest Brewer is a trigger happy shooter who doesn't know his limitations. Have you seen how bad Minnesota is? Who else was going to shoot the ball? He was forced to be a 1st or 2nd option and that's not who he is. Just look at what he did at the Univ of FL. He's at his best when he's asked to be an offensive contributor rather than the focal point. He was badly mis-used at Minn and his stock fell b/c of it.

Brewer's body is long and he's a quick, agile SF by NBA standards. He's a model specimen for D'Antoni's system. The knock on him is he can't shoot, but he does everything else well. Considering the fact that 3 of the Knicks starting 5 have no problems taking 15 shots a game, is it really so bad to have a guy like Brewer playing defense, getting boards and looking to slash? If he plays the game understanding he's the 4th option, he will EXCEL on this team.

so just a quick note on some characterizations of team performance here.  In describing the sonics after acquiring allen, you put a positive spin on a 18-12 finish (60% winning percentage) by leading with the number of wins; yet when describing the sixers after acquiring mutombo, you put a negative spin on a 15-12 finish (55.5% winning percentage) by leading with the number of losses.  Granted, a few percentage points can be the difference between making the playoffs and watching from home; but leading with wins in one case and losses in the other sends a confusing message that I think confuses your point.

Corey Brewer is an excellent team player,  willing to come off the bench and bring energy.  He loves defense, can slam with the best of them,   but his offense goes in streaks.   As a timberwolves fan, I was sorry to see him go but wish him well.   it would be worth taking a serious look at Corey,  and we are anxious to see with Anthony might bring for us.

Team chemistry is important in every sport, and perhaps more important in basketball than in any other. And that's just one more reason the Anthony trade was a bad deal for the Knicks.

The other main reason is Anthony's age. He's in the declining years of his career, and the Knicks gave up Gallinari, who's only 22 and has five or six years to improve before reaching his peak. Add in the 2014 first round draft choice, and it was a terrible deal.

Yes, the Knicks sold some tickets. But they also mortgaged their future for a player who won't help them get past the first round of the playoffs the entire time he's with the team.

We could get even more basic.  The use of alternating-current (AC) in the US is a historical artifact; the result of a feud.  Both AC and DC have pros and cons; but with today's technology, DC would be much easier to implement.  In the past, stepping voltages up and down was inefficient with DC, which is an easily solved problem today.  On the positive side, DC does not experience transmission losses.  And cities like Helsinki and Boston had DC systems into the 1960's.  It's interesting to think of what the grid would look like if we'd kept DC.

@Ben - jealous?
@Dan - you don't need Flash, unless you like slow running systems and crashes.
@Mira - why comment on Apple post if you don't like their superior products?
@CodeBlitz - that's what I'm talking about! :-)

Here we are, another couple of years down the road, and Intel is now perceived to be under attack by the ARM architecture, the de facto standard in mobile phones, which outsell PCs three to one worldwide.  Intel used to think its problem was keeping enough runway ahead of itself at the high end (servers), but that was when one server meant one CPU.  Today the high end of computing is parallel enough that legions of cheap CPUs (and now GPUs) on blades can get the job done.  The big problem (cost) for data centers is how much power they use, which determines how much heat they generate, which determines not just the electric bill but the size (cost) of the building and air conditioning system.  To minimize the cost of a data center, computing power per Watt is very important, and ARM outshines x86 on that spec.  It'll be very interesting to see how Intel's strategy plays out on that issue over the next several years.
I've never seen API spelled with periods.  Should I blame the e.d.i.t.o.r.?

I have grappled with a similar question since the iPad came out:  MacBook Air or the iPad?  New York Times tech editor answered the question very quickly:  “I use the MacBook Air.”  The Journal tech editor answered: “ I use both.”  One of the readers in this blog, Stephen Kopstein, explained it best.  Depends on what you intend to do with the device. His helpful comment is above. No matter which I get, I will likely want the other too.  For now, I will be standing in line to get the iPad2 as soon as I can.
www.familyeden.com is no longer existing at the time I tried to access it today, Feb. 25, 2011.

My wife and I recently moved our third car (small compact good milage bad traction in snow) in front of our house so we wouldn't be switching cars around all the time in the winter weather. This past Sunday a distracted driver went through a stop sign and smashed the front corner panel so hard that I can't start the car or open the hood. Did I mention that they failed to leave any information as to who hit the car or if they had insurance. OUCH! My insurance won't cover hit and run.

'Flash 10 required' notice.

Been able to watch Netflix streams for some time.

perhaps leonhardt will take a look at these statistics, and acknowledge, the fallacies of his several analyses that maintained rising wages during the recession.  Several urged Leonardt  to probe deeper  than the the faulty summary statistics that were compiled from government data, initially from Global Insight, but he unfortunately paid little heed.  Perhaps he can revisit the subject, and offer a bit of retraction in light of this and others more careful work.
If Governor Christie is not funding the public employees pensions as required by their contracts ($3 billion), is he violating the law?  Can contracts just be ignored?

The problem that we are experiencing is because there are too many workers in this world who are not unionized, and who are willing to work at slave rates in horrible conditions.  Don't blame unionized teachers in NJ; blame the capitalist "greed is good" crowd.

If Gov. Christie is a friend of teachers (but not their union), his rhetoric certainly does little to convey this message. Last fall he bent the truth and accused teachers of using children from their classes as "drug mules" to carry a voting message home to their parents.

His antipathy for the Union led directly to New Jersey's loss of $400 million in Race to the Top funding, something he originally tried to blame on the US Dept of Education, then on Pres. Obama, and finally on his then Commissioner of Education, Bret Schundler. When the DOE responded with a video proving their contention that the State was in fact provided with an opportunity to correct mistakes Christie had inserted into the application, the Governor went quiet.

And in a bit of unfortunate timing, just this week we've now learned that Christie's newly named replacement for Schundler, Christopher Cerf, was somehow involved with an educational consulting firm, Global Education Advisors, whose New Jersey address just happens to be Cerf's home. And despite the fact that this firm seems to have done very little consulting in the US, suddenly they have been awarded lucrative contracts in the Newark school system. Prior to his appointment in New Jersey, Cerf was a key administrator for the New York city schools' chancellor's office; in that post, it was discovered that he also held an equity share in the for-profit educational firm, Edison School Ventures.

Dig deeper, please.

Hercarnut, It's appalling that you would cite the teacher unions as an "anathema" to the education of "our" children. First, it takes a great deal of patience, compassion, and knowledge to be a good teacher. With that being said, I can't believe you or anyone else would go as far to paint us as some kind of money-sucking spawn that just eat up tax payer dollars (as we are tax payers as well). I am a young teacher, in my third year, and I really can not convey to you how hard I work to make the world a better place. A place where young people have the tools to understand and represent themselves. A place where young people can believe in themselves and their voice. I think what is being forgotten here is that the middle class needs an avenue that ensures good jobs that pay well and provide benefits, and we deserve it, especially teachers. The amount of stress and work that is put on each and every teacher to "teach" someone else's child to be an upstanding citizen, while also teaching important subject matter, is not an easy task. In my school district we are required to continue our education to the graduate level (on our own dime) and many of us stay long hours after our “pay” day is over to ensure that our students are the best they can be. “Our” children should refer to all of the children in the U.S. and we should be uniting with the parents, as we are often doing the job the parents don’t know how to do on their own. I hope that you can see teachers and teachers unions as a force of good in this world. We are a part of the few left that are not out to make a profit, like some of these greedy, snake-y governors that you are supporting.
For the explanation for Christie & Co's popularity google Mark Ames "We the Spiteful".

Christie is a typicaal  wing radical right Republican taking advantage  that Democrats don't scream and yell like he does.  Picking on teachers , police and firfighters while letting Wall Street Tycoons ( many of whom live in NJ) walk away with billions in untaxed swindled money is digusting.  If you added up all the NJ teachers, fighters and police pay you come up with a fraction of the payroll/bonuses of crooks at Golman Sachs.  Also what about Conress and Senators who pay zero in health care. Teachers are key to our future econmomy and democracy.  Cutting them down is downright UnAmerican
Koch Bros and others of their ilk = Welfare Queens. Teachers....not so much.

And so it goes. Pretty soon anything that the average American citizen was once entitled to and able to reasonably afford will be a marketable commodity only available to the highest bidder. Security, privacy, health, jobs, homes, and now a decent education. It's only a matter of time before the brownshirts start marching in the streets and smashing windows.
Gov. Christie, an obviously well-nourished Republican, would do well to avoid invocations of poverty-stricken families forced to survive on public assistance.

The "dumbing down" of America is alive and well. Americans are being led like sheep to vote strongly against their own best interests.
Maybe the middle class, or what's left of it, will receive a wake up call as a result of the actions taken by the Republicans in New Jersey, Wisconsin, etc. etc..
You vote for these people, Republicans, your going to get what you paid for.
Soon we're all going to be rich or poor. No in between. Wow, sounds kinda like the Middle East?
